dt: {bc}to utter with obvious effort or with a deep breath

dt.t: a spent horse gasping and {it}heaving{/it} his chest

dt: {bc}to displace (something, such as a rock stratum or a mineral vein) especially by a fault
{bc}to draw, pull, or haul on (something, such as a rope)

dt.t: The boat {it}heaved{/it} up and down on the waves.

dt: {bc}to move a ship in a specified direction or manner
{bc}to rise or become thrown or raised up

dt.t: Roads had begun to {wi}heave{/wi} with frost.

dt: {bc}to strain or labor to do something difficult {bc}{sx|struggle||}
{bc}to halt the headway of a ship (as by positioning a sailboat with the jib aback and the rudder turned sharply to windward)

pt: {sc}lift{/sc} {sc}raise{/sc} {sc}rear{/sc} {sc}elevate{/sc} {sc}hoist{/sc} {sc}heave{/sc} {sc}boost{/sc} mean to move from a lower to a higher place or position. {sc}lift{/sc} usually implies exerting effort to overcome resistance of weight.
{sc}raise{/sc} carries a stronger implication of bringing up to the vertical or to a high position.
{sc}rear{/sc} may add an element of suddenness to {sc}raise{/sc}.

pt.t: suddenly {it}reared{/it} itself up on its hind legs

pt: {sc}elevate{/sc} may replace {sc}lift{/sc} or {sc}raise{/sc} especially when exalting or enhancing is implied.
{sc}hoist{/sc} implies lifting something heavy especially by mechanical means.
{sc}heave{/sc} implies lifting and throwing with great effort or strain.
{sc}boost{/sc} suggests assisting to climb or advance by a push.

et: Middle English {it}heven{/it}, from Old English {it}hebban{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}hevan{/it} to lift, Latin {it}capere{/it} to take
shortdef: to utter with obvious effort or with a deep breath

dt: {bc}an upthrust of ground or pavement caused by freezing of moist soil

shortdef: an upthrust of ground or pavement caused by freezing of moist soil —called also frost heaving
